Award.AwardTitle: The genomic and ecological context of a major gene under selection in natural populations
Award.AbstractNarration:
A new generation of technology potentially allows researchers to uncover the genetic basis of specific traits in natural populations. This knowledge can be applied to understand in detail how populations evolve and respond genetically to environmental changes. This project will study a dramatic example of a specific trait, black coat color in dogs, which has been transferred to gray wolves (the ancestor of domestic dogs) uniquely in North America. This is the first example of a genetic mutation that appeared under domestication and has been widely successful in nature. The project will apply novel molecular and analytical techniques to integrate detailed molecular data with detailed data on coat color variation and ecology to understand how and why this mutation has been so successful in nature.

The results of this study will provide a detailed genetic understanding of the evolutionary forces responsible for causing the black mutation to sweep through North American wolf populations. These results support development of more general models of how selection acts on traits important to organismal survival and performance and are useful in predicting how populations can respond genetically to environmental change. The project will provide interdisciplinary and quantitative training for students and post-doctoral scientists, novel tools and models with broad applications, and information to the public through collaboration with museum programs and development of an interactive website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Black wolves are common in North America, but rare elsewhere in the World. It was discovered that the gene for black coat color is derived from ancient admixture between black dogs and gray wolves in North America and has swept to high frequency across the continent due to some unknown, unique selective advantage. This proposal aimed to uncover the history of spread and the molecular signal of selection at the black gene. The major goal is to try to understand the evolutionary causes and context of this remarkable event through application of cutting edge molecular techniques. We sequence over 8 million base pairs of DNA from over 600 wolves, including some from the Old World where  black wolves have independently appeared due to hybridization with dogs. We found evidence for an intense signal of selection at the black gene in North American wolves, but no association with habitat. This indicated that camouflage was not the reason for its successl; rather, the gene probably functions in immune processes, since it is a gene in a class of beta defensin genes whose primary role is in immunity. We pinpoint the area where the gene was first transferred to wolves from domestic dogs, and estimate how intense the selection was at locus and model its spread. We show that black coat color is experiencing current intense selection in the Yellowstone National Park wold population, which may relate to persistent exposure to distemper which resides in neighboring dog populations. Finally, we use pedigree data to estimate the mutation rate at the black gene, which allows a more precise estimate of selection at the gene.

Our completed genome sequencing and genotyping efforts have provided one of largest population genetic datasets for a wild vertebrate, particularly outside of primates and can be used to test additional hypotheses about adaptation and natural selection by a variety of researchers.  We have now provided wolf genomes for other investigators in an open database for use in  research and the first ancient complete mtDNA genomes of wolves. In fact, we have been contacted by many other scientists who are interested in the application of our results to their own studies. We have also been contacted by biology teachers who were interested in discussing our papers in their classroom, and environmental non-profit organizations who wanted to learn more about current research on wolves.
